resources.string: Don\'t have an account? Create an account!
This field should not be Empty!!
Username field should not be greater than 30 character
Invalid Phone number(must be begin 77 or 78 or 79 )

This application offers you three main sections:

 1- The Mental health section: to take care of your mental health.

 2- The physical health section: to take care of your physical health.

 3- The Nutrition System section: provides a detailed report on the diet.

 There is also a test section to give you a report if you have depression or not.

string-array.name: mentalNames
string-array.item: Depression
Schizophrenia
Social phobia
Bipolar
Obsessive compulsive
Insomnia

string-array.name: effects
string-array.item: - Feeling sad or low.\n- Being unable to enjoy things that normally bring you pleasure.\n- Low self-esteem and self-confidence.
- Reduced or lack of ability to function normally.\n- Seeing or hearing things that don\'t exist.\n- Lack the ability to experience pleasure.
- Worry about everyday activities, such as meeting strangers.\n- Find it difficult to do things when others are watching.\n- Fear being criticised, avoid eye contact or have low self-esteem.
- Unusually intense emotion.\n- Changes in sleep patterns and activity levels.\n- Uncharacteristic behaviors—often without recognizing their likely harmful or undesirable effects.
- Unwanted and unpleasant thought, image or urge that repeatedly enters your mind.\n- Repetitive behaviour or mental act that you feel you need to do.\n- Feelings of anxiety, disgust or unease.

- Difficulty falling asleep at night.
- Waking up during the night.
- Not feeling well-rested after a night's sleep.
- Irritability, depression or anxiety.
- Ongoing worries about sleep.

string-array.name: causesM
string-array.item: - Lack of support.\n- Difficult childhood experiences.\n- Stressful living conditions.
- Having a family history of schizophrenia.\n- Taking mind-altering drugs during teen years and young adulthood.\n- Exposure to toxins or viruses that may impact brain development.
- Family conflicts, domestic violence, and divorce.\n- Death of or desertion by a parent.\n- Maternal stress during pregnancy or infancy.
- Brain Structure and Functioning.\n- Genetics.
- Genetics.\n- A result of changes in your body\'s own natural chemistry.

- Stress.
- Travel or work schedule.
- Poor sleep habits.
- Eating too much late in the evening.

string-array.name: treatments
string-array.item: - Speak to people with similar experiences.\n- Be kind to yourself.\n- Be kind to yourself.
- Occupational therapists.\n- Social workers.\n- Pharmacists.
- Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT).\n- Guided self-help.
- Medications.\n- Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).\n-Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS).
- Psychological therapy.\n- Medicine.\n- Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).
- Avoid or limit naps.\n- Check your medications to see if they may contribute to insomnia.\n- Avoid large meals and beverages before bedtime.

string-array.name: bodyNames
string-array.item: Heart
Kidney
Liver
Pancreas

string-array.name: info
string-array.item:
- A fist-sized organ that pumps blood throughout your body.
- The primary organ of your circulatory system.
- Controls the rhythm and speed of your heart rate.
- Maintains your blood pressure.
- kidneys remove wastes and extra fluid from your body.\n- kidneys remove acid that is produced by the cells of your body.\n- Maintain a healthy balance of water, salts, and minerals in your blood.

- Located in the upper right-hand portion of the abdominal cavity.
- Shaped like a cone.
- Dark reddish-brown organ.
- Weighs about 3 pounds.

- An organ located in the abdomen.
- Plays an essential role in converting the food we eat into fuel for the body's cells.
- Helps in digestion.
- Regulates blood sugar.

string-array.name: diseasesAfflicted
string-array.item: - Heart attack (myocardial infarction).\n- Congestive heart failure.\n- Arrhythmia.
- kidney failure.\n- Glomerulonephritis.\n- Lupus Nephritis.
- Hepatitis A.\n- Fatty liver disease.\n- Liver cancer.
- Diabetes.\n- Gallstone Pancreatitis.\n- Cholecystitis.

string-array.name: causesB
string-array.item: - A part of the heart muscle doesn\'t get enough blood.\n- Coronary artery disease (CAD).\n- Beat too slowly, too quickly, or irregularly.
- High blood pressure.\n- Diabetes.\n- Physical injury.
- Viruses.\n- Drugs.\n- Inherited diseases.
- Gallstones.\n- Certain medications.\n- Cystic fibrosis.

string-array.name: treatmentsB
string-array.item: - Exercise moderately for at least 150 minutes per week.\n- Limit your sodium intake.\n- Manage your stress with healthy strategies.
- Dialysis.\n- Kidney transplant.
- Dandelion.\n- Milk Thistle.\n- Liver Transplantation.
- A low-fat diet.\n- Antibiotics.\n- Vitamins.

resources.string:
- Make most of your meal vegetables and fruits – ½ of your plate.

 Aim for color and variety, and remember that potatoes don’t count as vegetables on the Healthy Eating Plate because of their negative impact on blood sugar.


 - Go for whole grains – ¼ of your plate.

 Whole and intact grains—whole wheat, barley, wheat berries, quinoa, oats, brown rice, and foods made with them, such as whole wheat pasta—have a milder effect on blood sugar and insulin than white bread, white rice, and other refined grains.


 - Protein power – ¼ of your plate.

 Fish, poultry, beans, and nuts are all healthy, versatile protein sources—they can be mixed into salads, and pair well with vegetables on a plate. Limit red meat, and avoid processed meats such as bacon and sausage.


 - Healthy plant oils – in moderation.

 Choose healthy vegetable oils like olive, canola, soy, corn, sunflower, peanut, and others, and avoid partially hydrogenated oils, which contain unhealthy trans fats. Remember that low-fat does not mean “healthy.”


 - Drink water, coffee, or tea.

 Skip sugary drinks, limit milk and dairy products to one to two servings per day, and limit juice to a small glass per day.


 - Stay active.

 The red figure running across the Healthy Eating Plate’s placement is a reminder that staying active is also important in weight control.
C. More than half the days
